contextId.information: John speaks of death as if it were a person or animal that could run away. AT: "they will not be able to die" or "they will not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The earth is spoken of as if it were a living thing,  and a hole in the earth is spoken of as if it were a mouth that could drink up the water.  AT: "A hole in the ground opened up and the water went down into the hole" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed the river that the dragon was pouring out of his mouth

contextId.information: Babylon is spoken of as if it were a prostitute who has caused other people to sin along with her. This may well have a double meaning: literal sexual immorality and also the worship of false gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

These deeds are spoken of as if they were alive and able to follow those who did them. Possible meanings are 1)"others will know the good deeds these people have done" or 2)"God will reward them for their deeds."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here John speaks of the "voice" as if it were a person. AT: "someone spoke from the throne" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: a voice came out from the throne

contextId.information: Here John describes "death" as a person with power. AT: "These people will not experience the second death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Over these the second death has no power

contextId.information: Here John speaks of fire as if it were alive. AT: "God sent fire from heaven to burn them up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: fire came down from heaven and devoured them

contextId.information: John describes heaven and earth as if they were people who were trying to escape God's judgment. This means that God completely destroyed the old heaven and earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The earth and the heaven fled away from his presence, but there was no place for them to go

contextId.information: Here John speaks of the sea, death, and hades as if they were living persons.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The sea gave up the dead ... Death and hades gave up the dead

contextId.information: The angel speaks of Jerusalem as if it were a woman who is about to marry her groom, the Lamb. Jerusalem is metonymy for those who believers who will inhabit it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the bride, the wife of the Lamb
